metadata.case_name: Godhra Electricity Co. Ltd. & Anr. v. Gujarat State Electricity Board & Anr.

facts.text: Government of the Province of Bombay granted a licence by notification dated November 16, 1922, under S. 3 of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910 known as the Godhra Electric Licence, 1922 in favour of Lady Sulochana Chinubhai and Company, Ahmedabad.
Licence was signed on November 17, 1922 and notification granting it was published in the Bombay Government Gazette dated November 23, 1922.
Licence was transferred to the 1st appellant-company viz., the Godhra Electricity Co. Ltd.

Licence was for a period of 50 years initially from its commencement. Initial period of 50 years expired on the midnight intervening between the 15th and 16th November, 1972 according to the respondents.

Second respondent (Gujarat State Electricity Board) exercised option to purchase the undertaking of the 1st appellant by notice dated November 8, 1971 under s. 6(1) of the Act calling upon appellants to sell on midnight intervening between 15th and 16th November, 1972.

Appellants filed writ petition before Gujarat High Court challenging validity of notice dated November 8, 1971 and provisions of sections 6, 7 and 7A of the Act as ultra vires Articles 14, 19(1)(f), 19(1)(g) and 31 of the Constitution.
High Court dismissed the petition by judgment dated 15th/16th October, 1973.
Government of Gujarat issued notification under rule 115 of the Defence of India Rules taking over management of the undertaking on November 18, 1973.
State Government handed over the undertaking to the 2nd respondent on December 21, 1973.
Clause 11(a) of the licence states that option to purchase given by S. 7 of the Act exercisable first on expiration of 50 years computed from commencement of the licence.

Clause 2(e) of the licence: 'The date of the notification by the Government of Bombay in the Bombay Government Gazette that this licence has been granted is in this licence referred to as the commencement of this licence.'

Rule 17 of Indian Electricity Rules, 1922 provides for publication of licence in local official gazette to notify that it has been granted. Rule 18 states date of notification under Rule 17 deemed date of commencement.
Licence subsequently amended referring to grant in notification No. 177 dated 16th November 1922 published pages 2652-2656 Bombay Govt Gazette 23rd Nov 1922.
2nd appellant is shareholder and Managing Director of 1st appellant company.

legal_issues.text: What is the date of commencement of the licence - date of notification (November 16, 1922), signing (November 17, 1922), or publication (November 23, 1922)? Did the 50 years period expire on midnight intervening 15th-16th November 1972 making the notice valid?

Are provisions of sub-section (6) of S. 6 of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910 invalid as abridging rights under Articles 19(1)(f) and 19(1)(g) by requiring delivery of undertaking pending determination and payment of purchase price without provision for interest?
Does 2nd appellant, as shareholder and MD, have standing to challenge under Art 19?

petitioner_arguments.text: Date of commencement of licence was date of publication in Gazette viz. November 23, 1922 not notification date November 16, 1922, so 50 years period did not expire on November 15, 1972 and notice requiring sale on that date was bad.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Clause 2(e) of licence; signing date Nov 17

petitioner_arguments.text: Provisions of s.6(6) invalid as abridge Art 19(1)(f) and 19(1)(g) by postponing payment of purchase price till after determination by arbitrator, requiring delivery without payment unlike pre-1959 law.
2nd appellant's right to carry on business through company and share in property impaired.

respondent_arguments.text: Date of commencement was November 16, 1922 date of notification granting licence per clause 2(e) and rules.

After valid notice exercising option, licensee has no right to carry on business, so s.6(6) does not abridge Art 19(1)(g). Interest implicit in s.7A or awardable by arbitrator/common law; enforceable in suit.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: S.6(6), S.7A Indian Electricity Act; Art 19(1)(g)

court_reasoning.text: Date of commencement is date of notification November 16, 1922 per clause 2(e) read with Rule 18; publication date is for notification but commencement deemed notification date even if signed later. Subsequent amendment distinguishes notification date and publication.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No doubt date of commencement was November 16, 1922; notice valid.

court_reasoning.text: Discusses admissibility of subsequent conduct/interpretations for ambiguous documents; parties' amendment shows they distinguished notification (16th) from publication (23rd).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Subsequent interpreting statements admissible for latent ambiguity.

court_reasoning.text: S.6(6) unreasonable: requires delivery pending purchase price determination without arbitrator power to award interest (only market value at delivery); interest via suit does not mitigate; violates Art 19(1)(f),(g). Pre-1959 required payment before delivery.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Arbitrator under s.7A cannot award interest; licensee must be compensated by payment or interest before delivery.

court_reasoning.text: 2nd appellant shareholder has standing as state action impairs company rights and thus his rights to business and shares.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Shareholder entitled to protection under Art 19 if company rights impaired.

holdings.text: Date of commencement of licence is November 16, 1922; notice exercising option valid.
S.6(6) of Indian Electricity Act violates Art 19(1)(f) and 19(1)(g); no valid purchase as delivery without payment/interest provision unlawful.
2nd appellant has locus standi to challenge.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gujarat Electricity Board v. Shantilal R. Desai
precedents_cited.relevance: Strict compliance with S.6(1) required for valid exercise of option.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gujarat Electricity Board v. Girdharlal Motilal
precedents_cited.relevance: Failure to comply with S.6(1) renders option ineffective.
Prior negotiations inadmissible for contract construction.

precedents_cited.case_name: James Miller and Partners Ltd. v. Whitworth Street Estates (Manchester) Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Subsequent conduct inadmissible for contract construction.
Reaffirms exclusion of subsequent conduct; distinguishes land titles.

precedents_cited.case_name: Abdulla Ahmed v. Animendra Kissen Mitter
precedents_cited.relevance: Extrinsic evidence permissible for doubt in instrument meaning.

precedents_cited.case_name: R.C. Cooper v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Shareholder can challenge if company rights impaired.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bennett Coleman Co. v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Shareholders' Art 19 rights protected if company affected.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kalyan Singh v. State of U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Final scheme extinguishes permit rights; not analogous to licensee rights without payment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Toronto City Corporation v. Toronto Railway Corporation
M.P. Electricity Board v. Central India Electric Supply Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Arbitrator under Act has no jurisdiction for interest.

precedents_cited.case_name: Upper Jamuna Valley Electricity Supply Co. Ltd. v. Municipal Corporation of Delhi

statutes_cited.name: Indian Electricity Act, 1910
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs licence grant, option to purchase, delivery pending price, price determination; amendments by Act 32 of 1959 challenged.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Electricity (Amendment) Act, 1959
statutes_cited.relevance: Amended ss.6,7 introducing changes reducing periods, notice, purchasers, delivery pending payment, no waiver, exclude service lines.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Electricity Rules, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Publication notifies grant; notification date deemed commencement.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Challenged as ultra vires for unreasonableness in purchase/delivery.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed to extent indicated: held s.6(6) unconstitutional violating Art 19(1)(f),(g); no valid purchase, taking delivery unlawful; directed State Electricity Board to redeliver undertaking to licensee; set aside High Court judgment.
outcome.relief_granted: Redelivery of undertaking to licensee; declaration s.6(6) invalid.

key_quotes.text: "the date of the notification granting the licence was November 16, 1922. There can, therefore, be no doubt that the date of commencement of the licence was November 16, 1922."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Determines validity of purchase notice date.

key_quotes.text: "We hold that S. 6(6) violates the fundamental right under Art. 19(1)(g) and 19(1)(f) of the 2nd appellant."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding striking down provision as unconstitutional.

key_quotes.text: "In the result we hold that there was no valid purchase of the undertaking and that taking delivery of the undertaking was unlawful."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Final determination leading to redelivery order.
